title: 104_hr345
content:
The "Language of Government Act of 1995" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The Congress recognizes the diverse backgrounds in the United States and the benefits of unity through a common language. English has historically been the common language, promoting efficiency and fairness in government business. The Congress recognizes the benefits of unity through a common language, English, for official government business. The amendments made are not intended to discriminate or restrict rights, nor discourage the use of other languages in nonofficial capacities. The amendments do not repeal existing laws unless they directly conflict with the use of English for official government business. The Congress recognizes the benefits of unity through a common language, English, for official government business. Title 4, United States Code, is amended to establish English as the official language of the government. The Congress recognizes the benefits of unity through a common language, English, for official government business. Title 4, United States Code, is amended to establish English as the official language of the government. The official language of the Government of the United States is English. The Government shall preserve and enhance the role of English as the official language, including encouraging opportunities for individuals to learn English. Government activities must be conducted in English, and no person shall be denied services provided in English. The text chunk discusses the entitlement of every person in the United States to communicate with the Government in English, receive and contribute information in English, and be informed of official orders in English. It also mentions that any person alleging injury from a violation of this chapter has standing to sue in the courts of the United States. Additionally, it provides definitions, stating that the term 'Government' includes all branches of the Government of the United States and its employees. The term 'official business' refers to governmental actions, documents, or policies enforceable by the Government of the United States, excluding informational or educational actions, non-enforceable documents, actions related to international relations, trade, or commerce, actions protecting public health or safety, and actions protecting victims' rights. The term 'official business' excludes actions related to international relations, trade, or commerce, and actions protecting public health or safety. It includes actions that protect the rights of victims of crimes or criminal defendants, and documents utilizing terms from languages other than English. SEC. 4. ENGLISH LANGUAGE REQUIREMENT FOR CEREMONIES FOR ADMISSION OF NEW CITIZENS.

    All public ceremonies administering the oath of allegiance must be conducted in English. The amendment takes effect 60 days after enactment.

SEC. 5. PREEMPTION.

    This Act and its amendments do not override any State laws.
